bibl.title: Notes from Liberian Legation In U.S. to Department of State, 1862-1898 T807

body.div1:
The Liberian Government having been made cognisant of the said agreement, submits the following propositions thereon: Considering that the district comprising its south eastern teritory situated between Cape Palmas and the San Pedro River were included within the limits of the State of Maryland in Liberia as far back as the years 1835-50, and that no counter claim was set up at that time by any European State.
Considering also that the State of Maryland in Liberia was peacefully incorporated with the Republic of Liberia in the year 1854, that said incoportation was then and there published to the world, and that no protest agaisnt it was made by any European State, that therefore said incorporation has had the sanction and knowledgement of the civilized world for nearly half a century, and that it is only within the last six years that
any
any claim to said territory have been preferred by the Government of France.
Considering also that these territories are responsible for a portion of the Foreign debt of the Republic,
Considering also that America Liberian nuscious and schools have in the past and are at present established in the said districts and up the Cavalla River.
Considering that the Map of Africa recently published by the Royal Geographical Novels of the Belgium show the proposed inferior boundary of the Republic at its greatest width at Roporo in the Condo country, which would only give the Republic an interior extent of about 40 miles; and that the whole of the Condo COuntry was formally ceded to the Republic by King Momora Sav in the years 1868-69.
Considering also that the countries between Monrovia and the interior slope of the Western Mandingo plateau were explored by Benjamin Anderson at the instance of the Liberian government during the years 1868,1873, and 1874 and confirmed to the Republic by Special Treaties, and now set down in
the
the French map of that region as unexplored and therefore liable to become a protectorate of France.
Considering also that the present or prospective deluincitation* according to the Map referred so would cut off or separate from the Republic populations that have been peacefully under its sphere of influence for the last 40 years, and would also dperive the Republic of all acess to the River Niger, contrary to the Riverland doctrine now acknowledged in, Europe as binding with respect to European acquisitors on the African Continent.
COnsidering also that the Republic of Liberia is not a European State, but was an Independent African Government in exsistence long before the era of the Berlin Conference and was in possession of said teritory at a period considerably inferior to the convening of said Conference, and was not invited to participate in its deliberations, and ought not therefore to be bound by the rules thereat prescibed for the conduct of European Powers in making fresh acquistions of territory in Africa, and that Republic seeks only that territory which has for so long period been acknowledged to
rightfully
rightfully belong to her and the right of her Riverland.
For the above reasons the Republic considers that her boundaries ought in all right and justice to extend form the Mannual River on the North to the San Pedro River on the South, and inferior wars from the Sea coast to the River Niger in accordance with the Riverlands law. This regualtion of her boundaries would be very little moment to the European States who have acquired such extensive Empires in Africa, but is of vital importance to the Republic of Liberia and would further more sufficently meet her just aspirations.
The Republic therefore protest against the conclusion of the said Agreement, so far as the deprivation of Liberian territorty by France is concerned and solicits the good offices of the United States Government to avert her impending loss of territory on her sea board and inferior.
E.T.Barelay
